column4: So I'm not using Ubuntu anymore. It worked fine until about two months ago, possibly after an update, after which it failed to recognise my Buffalo Wireless-G USB Adapter which had been working perfectly beforehand. Ideas, please?
But I can't, since I cannot access the internet within it
I thought it was an intermittant fault with the adapter. But it works fine in Windows
Any ideas regarding my Buffalo Wireless-G USB adapter not workin? I've searched the forum, there are posts but no answers.
just telling us it's not working really doesn't give enough information to help you. Does ifconfig ssay you have an IP? Does iwconfig show you connected to a network?
Obviously, I'm not in Ubuntu right now.
yes, that makes it very hard to help you
ok, do you have the specific error
No, just that "no network connection is present"
Or something. Two computers and a red cross where the wireless indicator should be.
Lights do appear when it boots. But Ubuntu rejects it before it comes up with the log in screen

I don't use gnome, so what the gui shows doesn't mean anything to me. Try starting ubuntu and doing 'ifconfig yournetworkdevice' to see if you have an IP, and then 'iwconfig yournetworkdevice' and check if essid is set to the name of your network device.
essid is set to the name of your wireless network, sorry, not device
If the essid is wrong, what then?
then you're trying to connect to the wrong network.
try 'sudo iwconfig yournetworkdevice essid yourwirelessnetwork; sudo dhclient yournetworkdevice'
you mean ubuntu isn't recongnizing your NIC?
I'm not sure, all I know that after boot it is almost as if my adapter isn't plugged in.
so it doesn't show up in ifconfig at all?
you can download the ubuntu CD's and use them
And they have all the latest updates?
a new CD should be pretty close, it might not be bleeding edge though
Well I have 8.04, but you're saying that the lastest iso might be 8.06+updates?
That should work... but I've never tried updating via CD, so I really don't know anything about it beyond that it should be possible.
